post_text: The “tee”rific teachers of MCPS are dedicated to getting students into the “swing” of distance learning!
shared_text:
Mayfield Intermediate School is feeling excited at The Magic Putting Place.
Yesterday at 7:14 PM · Manassas, VA ·

How cool are our teachers?!? Today's virtual PE lesson was putt-putt golf!! Students learned about persistence (Mr. Hinton never gave up!), applications of geometry (Go, Mr. Moore!), and good sportsmanship (Congratulations, Mr. Massey!). Between holes, students got out of their seats and engaged in calisthenics (push-ups, jumping jacks, etc).

We appreciate our teachers' creativity, enthusiasm, and dedication to our students. One more reason why #MayfieldISproud

#InspireInnovation #returnstronger

Congratulations to the Class of 2020!
When officials announced that holding a large graduation ceremony would not be possible, Osbourn High School administrators and staff adapted. With the help of many volunteers, OHS developed a plan so each of its 477 graduates could be celebrated. Adhering to strict health guidelines, Manassas City Public Schools provided each graduate an opportunity to receive their diploma, walk across the stage in their cap and gown and share the moment with a limited number of guests. Graduation was held over the course of five days (July 18 and 20-23) and livestreamed for those who could not be present. Each graduate was congratulated by Principal Mike Pflugrath, Superintendent Dr. Kevin Newman and City of Manassas School Board members. #OneOsbourn

With the hope to provide all Osbourn High School graduates with a safe, in‐person graduation experience, OHS has developed a plan in accordance with the CDC guidelines and Gov. Northam’s orders.
Graduation for the Class of 2020 will be held at Osbourn High School, rain or shine, on July 18 and July 20- 23, 2020. A letter with an individual prearranged date and appointment time was mailed to all graduating students/families the week of June 6, 2020.
“As your principal, I want to ensure that you and your parents/guardians have a safe and dignified opportunity to celebrate your accomplishments before you move on to the next chapter of your life,” said OHS Principal Mike Pflugrath. “Graduation is an accomplishment that is achieved thanks to the efforts of parents, guardians, siblings, relatives, community members, and more.”
Each graduate can bring 10 guests. Friends and family members that cannot attend in person can watch a live stream of graduation at: Osbourngraduation.com.
For more information, visit https://www.mcpsva.org/osbournhs or call (571) 377-7004.

Excellent job E.S.! You are a blossoming young scientist and we are so proud of you!
#bishuskypride #STEM #scientificinquiry
"PREDICT- I plan to test the surface tension of water and salt water, I predict that the salt water will have the strongest surface tension.
Constants:
1. The amount of water in each jar
2. Same coins to test the surface tension
3. The same technique when dropping the coins into the jars
Procedure:
1. Get 1 cup of water
2. Pour 1 cup of water into two separate jars
3. Then pour 1 TBS of salt in one jar
4. Put one coin at a time into the jar of salt water until surface tension brakes
5. Then after the surface tension broke, I dumped all the coins out to use the same coins in the water jar
6. Then I put one coin at a time in the jar of water till the surface tension broke
Outcome: I found out my hypothesis was wrong the jar with just water had the strongest surface tension then the salt water."

March 4 at 7:18 PM · Manassas, VA ·

Weems hosted its inaugural “Build a Bedtime Book Collection Family Night” Tuesday, March 3, 2020.
Although there was no school that day, students and their families packed Weems for the event which provided children an opportunity to select free books and visit the book fair. Each student was given a Weems bag that they could fill with donated books and had the chance to select a stuffed animal.
Families were invited to wear their pajamas and curl up with a blanket as they read together in the school’s gym. The event included family literacy activities, a photo booth, raffle drawings and a Make your own Book station.
Megan Gleason, an ESOL teacher at Weems, developed the idea and with the help of other teachers and administrators brought the vision to life.

Every Tuesday, eight extra feet enter the halls of Haydon Elementary School. They are the paws of Chloe and Radar, canines from Manassas Therapy Dogs. The dogs and their trainers sit with selected students who read out loud to the dogs once a week, practicing their fluency and other reading fundamentals in a safe and positive environment.
The Paws for Reading program is available to kindergarteners through fourth graders, allowing each grade five weeks with the therapy dogs. During week one, all the students from the grade level are introduced to the dogs and learn about therapy dogs and dog safety. For the remaining four weeks, selected students visit the dogs to practice their reading.
Paws for Reading is also available to kindergarteners at Jennie Dean Elementary.

Fourth graders at Round Elementary have been learning about how the nation was formed and the role of government. For their Project Based Learning (PBL) project, groups of students were tasked with developing their own nations. Those projects were presented to local government experts on Friday, February 7, 2020.
Representatives from the school board, city council and other organizations watched the student’s presentations about what roles leaders should have, what rights citizens should have and other functions of their new governments before providing them feedback. Government experts who participated include: Superintendent Dr. Newman, school board members Tim Demeria and Suzanne Seaberg, City of Manassas Mayor Parrish, Vice Mayor Pamela J. Sebesky and council members Theresa Coates Ellis and Ralph J. Short.
In an effort to prepare for their final presentations, Round students practiced their presentations in front of Osbourn government students. The government students offered the fourth graders advice and helped them prepare for the event.

This morning at Round Elementary School, special education teacher Mrs. Shannon Helton was awarded with a sign created and presented by two of her former students, now Osbourn High School students. Mrs. Helton, with the support of her instructional assistants Maria Aguirre and Lucila Rocha, has developed a Model Structured Teaching Classroom that incorporates physical organization, individual visual schedules, structured work systems, and visual supports for learning. Mrs. Helton engages in a continuous process of reflection and restructuring to best meet the needs of individual learners. The Model Structured Teaching Classroom will serve as a springboard for special education teachers to discuss the process of developing and restructuring learning environments for students with special learning needs. Questions about the Model Structured Teaching Classroom can be directed to Jennifer Macensky at jmacensky@mcpsva.org.
#RoundIsFamily #OneOsbourn

Additional achievements include earning three consecutive 1st Team All-District honors as a midfielder and being ranked as the 2nd best player in the Cedar Run District. Powell became only the second player in OHS program history to make 1st Team All-Region, also as a midfielder. On November 21st, she became the first player in OHS Field Hockey’s 12-year history to be selected to an All-State team, earning 2nd Team in the Player At-Large category. In addition to Dr. Newman, School Board Chairman Williams and School Board member Lisa Stevens, Powell is pictured with her Field Hockey coaches, Amanda Coombs, Debra Clark and Rebecca Innamorato. Congratulations!
